oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Low-energy planar magnetic defects in BaFe2As2: Nanotwins, twins, antiphase, and domain boundaries
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: KHAN, SN
ALAM, A
JOHNSON, DD
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: SUPERCONDUCTIVITY
PNICTIDES
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In BaFe2As2, structural and magnetic planar defects begin to proliferate below the structural phase transition, affecting descriptions of magnetism and superconductivity. We study, using density-functional theory, the stability and magnetic properties of competing antiphase and domain boundaries, twins and isolated nanotwins (twin nuclei), and spin excitations proposed and/or observed. These nanoscale defects have a very low surface energy (22-210 m Jm(-2)), with twins favorable to the mesoscale. Defects exhibit smaller moments confined near their boundaries-making a uniform-moment picture inappropriate for long-range magnetic order in real samples. Nanotwins explain features in measured pair distribution functions so should be considered when analyzing scattering data. All these defects can be weakly mobile and/or can have fluctuations that lower assessed "ordered" moments from longer spatial and/or time averaging and should be considered directly.
